title: 107_hr3041
content: The "Travel America Now Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. Congress finds that prior to September 11, 2001, the travel and tourism industry in the United States was a significant contributor to the economy, with millions employed and billions in expenditures. After the terrorist attacks, efforts were made to ensure the safety of travel and maintain confidence among travelers. Urgent measures were deemed necessary to support the industry and its workforce. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for revitalizing the US economy. The public should be encouraged to travel for both personal and business reasons to support the industry and generate cash flow. SEC. 3. PERSONAL TRAVEL CREDIT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for a Personal Travel Credit. The new section allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 ($1,000 for joint returns) and covers expenses for travel and lodging, excluding meals and entertainment. The new section allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses within the United States, involving an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and the farthest destination being at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence. The credit does not cover expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The new section allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses within the United States, involving an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility. The term 'commercial lodging facility' includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Special rules include denial of credit to dependents and the requirement to substantiate expenses. The new section allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses within the United States, involving an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility. Expenses must be substantiated by adequate records. No double benefit is allowed for expenses claimed under this section. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment date. A temporary increase in the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses is in effect until January 1, 2002. The amendment for net operating loss carryback for the travel and tourism industry is also included. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. Rules relating to travel and tourism industry losses define the term 'travel or tourism loss' and 'travel or tourism business'. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. Travel or tourism business includes commercial transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, convention facilities, and other specified services. Losses are treated similarly to specified liability losses for tax purposes. Taxpayers can elect to adjust the carryback period without certain restrictions. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. Taxpayers can elect to adjust the carryback period without restrictions, and related taxpayers can credit the loss against taxable income earned during the 5-year carryback period. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year, with related taxpayers able to credit the loss against taxable income earned during the 5-year carryback period. The effective date for these amendments applies to taxable years ending before, on, or after the date of enactment of the Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as outlined in article I, section 8 of the United States Constitution.
